a.g: The revelation of the Qur'an is from Allah, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
Indeed, We have sent down to you the Book, [O Muhammad], in truth. So worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion.

Unquestionably, for Allah is the pure religion. And those who take protectors besides Him [say], "We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position." Indeed, Allah will judge between them concerning that over which they differ. Indeed, Allah does not guide he who is a liar and [confirmed] disbeliever.

Indeed, to Allah belongs the religion of pure sincerity [al-din al-khalis]. And He, the Exalted, said: "Except for those who repent, reform, and hold fast to Allah and make their religion [din] pure for Allah." And He, the Exalted, said: "So whoever hopes for the meeting with his Lord, let him do righteous work and not associate anyone in the worship of his Lord." This was revealed concerning one who acts for Allah but loves to be praised for it. And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Three things, concerning them the heart of a believing man is not treacherous: sincerity of action [ikhlas al-'amal] for Allah." And from Mus'ab ibn Sa'd, from his father, who said: My father thought he had superiority over those beneath him among the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah, Mighty and Majestic, grants victory to this community only through its weak ones, their supplication, and their sincerity [ikhlas]." And from al-Hasan, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah, the Exalted, says: 'Sincerity [al-ikhlas] is a secret from My secrets; I have deposited it in the heart of whom I love from among My servants.'" And 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, said: "Do not be concerned with the smallness of the action, but be concerned with its acceptance. For the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Mu'adh ibn Jabal: 'Make the action sincere [akhliṣ al-'amal], and a little of it will suffice you.'" And he, peace be upon him, said: "There is no servant who makes his action pure [yukhlis] for Allah for forty days except that the springs of wisdom [yanabi' al-hikmah] will appear from his heart [qalb] upon his tongue." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The first to be questioned on the Day of Resurrection are three: A man whom Allah granted knowledge ['ilm]. So Allah, the Exalted, will say: 'What did you do with what you knew?' He will say: 'My Lord, I would stand in prayer during the night and its ends during the day.' He will say: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say: 'You have lied. Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is a scholar. Behold, it was said.' And a man whom Allah granted wealth. So Allah, the Exalted, will say: 'I have bestowed favor upon you, so what did you do?' He will say: 'My Lord, I would give charity with it during the night and its ends during the day.' He will say: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say: 'You have lied. Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is generous. Behold, it was said.' And a man who was killed in the path of Allah, the Exalted. So Allah, the Exalted, will say: 'What did you do?' He will say: 'My Lord, You commanded with struggle [jihad], so I fought until I was killed.' He will say: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say: 'You have lied. Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is courageous. Behold, it was said.'" Abu Hurayrah said: Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, struck my thigh and said: "O Abu Hurayrah, those are the first of creation for whom the fire of Hell [nar jahannam] will be heated."

a.g: If Allah had intended to take a son, He could have chosen from what He creates whatever He willed. Exalted is He; He is Allah, the One, the Prevailing.

He created the heavens and earth in truth. He wraps the night over the day and wraps the day over the night and has subjected the sun and the moon, each running [its course] for a specified term. Unquestionably, He is the Exalted in Might, the Perpetual Forgiver.

He created you from one soul. Then He made from it its mate, and He produced for you from the grazing livestock eight mates. He creates you in the wombs of your mothers, creation after creation, within three darknesses. That is Allah, your Lord; to Him belongs dominion. There is no deity except Him, so how are you averted?

If you disbelieve - indeed, Allah is Free from need of you. And He does not approve for His servants disbelief. And if you are grateful, He approves it for you; and no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. Then to your Lord is your return, and He will inform you about what you used to do. Indeed, He is Knowing of that within the breasts.

Indeed, for this reason the Sacred Law [al-Shar'] has magnified the command regarding the killing of children and regarding infanticide [al-wa'd], for it is a prevention of the completion of existence [tamam al-wujud]. To this, the one who said, "Coitus interruptus [al-'azl] is one of the two forms of infanticide," alluded. Therefore, the one who engages in intercourse is striving to complete what God, Exalted is He, loves to be completed, and the one who turns away is nullifying and wasting what God dislikes to be wasted. And due to God's love [mahabbah] for the survival [baqa'] of souls [al-nufus], He commanded feeding and urged towards it, and He expressed it through the worship of the loan, saying: "Who is it that will lend God a goodly loan?" If you say: Your statement that the survival of progeny and the soul is beloved [mahbub] implies that their annihilation [fana'] is disliked [makruh] in the sight of God, and this creates a distinction between death [al-mawt] and life [al-hayah] in relation to God's will [iradah]. Yet it is known that everything is by God's will [mashiyyah], and that God is Self-Sufficient [ghani] over all the worlds. So from where is their death distinguished from their life, or their survival from their annihilation, in His sight? Know that this statement is true, but a falsehood is intended by it. For what we have mentioned does not contradict attributing all existent things to God's will [iradah]—their good and their evil, their benefit and their harm. However, love [al-mahabbah] and dislike [al-karahiyah] are opposites, and both do not contradict the will [al-iradah]. For many a willed thing is disliked, and many a willed thing is beloved. Disobediences [al-ma'asi] are disliked, and they, despite the dislike, are willed. And acts of obedience [al-ta'at] are willed, and their determined existence is willed, beloved, and pleasing. As for disbelief [al-kufr] and evil [al-sharr], we do not say it is pleasing [mardiy] and beloved [mahbub], but rather it is willed [murad]. And God, Exalted is He, has said: "Nor is He pleased with disbelief for His servants." So how can annihilation [al-fana'] be in relation to God's love [mahabbah] and dislike [karahiyah] like survival [al-baqa']? For He, Exalted is He, says: "I have not hesitated in anything as I hesitate in seizing the soul of My believing servant. He dislikes death, and I dislike to distress him, yet death is inevitable for him." His statement, "death is inevitable for him," is an allusion to the precedence of the will [al-iradah] and the decree [al-taqdir] mentioned in His saying, Exalted is He: "We have decreed death among you," and in His saying, Exalted is He: "Who created death and life." And there is no contradiction between His saying, Exalted is He: "We have decreed death among you," and His saying: "and I dislike to distress him." However, clarifying the truth in this requires verifying the meaning of will [al-iradah], love [al-mahabbah], and dislike [al-karahiyah], and elucidating their realities [haqa'iq].

a.g: And when adversity touches man, he calls upon his Lord, turning to Him [alone]; then when He bestows on him a favor from Himself, he forgets Him whom he called upon before, and he attributes to Allah equals to mislead [people] from His way. Say, "Enjoy your disbelief for a little; indeed, you are of the companions of the Fire."

Is one who is devoutly obedient during periods of the night, prostrating and standing [in prayer], fearing the Hereafter and hoping for the mercy of his Lord, [like one who does not]? Say, "Are those who know equal to those who do not know?" Only they will remember [who are] people of understanding.

a.g: Say, "O My servants who have believed, fear your Lord. For those who do good in this world is good, and the earth of Allah is spacious. Indeed, the patient will be given their reward without account."

Vol1 book 6
Indeed, He has linked victory to patience [sabr], so the Almighty said: "Yes, if you are patient [tasbiroo] and fear Allah and they come upon you in this onslaught, your Lord will reinforce you with five thousand angels, marked." And He has gathered for the patient [sabireen] matters not gathered for others, as He said: "Those are the ones upon whom are blessings from their Lord and mercy, and it is they who are the guided." So guidance [huda], mercy [rahma], and blessings [salawat] are gathered for the patient [sabireen]. To exhaust all the verses regarding the station of patience [sabr] would be lengthy. As for the narrations, He (peace be upon him) said: "Patience [sabr] is half of faith [iman]," according to what will come regarding the aspect of it being half. And He (peace be upon him) said: "The least of what you have been given is certainty [yaqin] and the resolve of patience [sabr]. Whoever is given his share of these two will not care what he missed of night prayer and daytime fasting. And for you to be patient [tasbiroo] upon what you are upon is more beloved to me than for every one of you to meet me with the like of the deeds of all of you. But I fear that the world [dunya] will be opened up to you after me, so you will deny one another, and the people of the heavens will deny you. At that time, whoever is patient [sabara] and seeks reward will attain the perfection of his reward." Then he recited the saying of the Almighty: "What is with you will be exhausted, and what is with Allah is lasting. And We will surely give those who were patient [sabaru] their reward," the verse. And Jabir narrated that he (peace be upon him) was asked about faith [iman], and he said: "Patience [sabr] and generosity." And he also said: "Patience [sabr] is a treasure from the treasures of Paradise." And he was asked once, "What is faith [iman]?" He said: "Patience [sabr]." This resembles his saying (peace be upon him): "The Hajj is 'Arafah," meaning the greatest part of Hajj is 'Arafah. And he (peace be upon him) also said: "The best of deeds are those you compel your souls [nufus] to do." And it was said that Allah the Almighty revealed to Dawud (peace be upon him): "Adorn yourself with My attributes, and among My attributes is that I am the Patient [al-Sabur]." And in the hadith of 'Ata' from Ibn 'Abbas: When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) entered upon the Ansar, he said: "Are you believers [mu'minoon]?" They were silent. 'Umar said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "And what is the sign of your faith [iman]?" They said: "We give thanks in ease, we are patient [nasbiru] in hardship, and we are content with the decree." He (peace be upon him) said: "Believers [mu'minoon], by the Lord of the Ka'bah!" And he (peace be upon him) said: "When the Day of Resurrection comes, the people of deeds will be brought, and their deeds will be weighed in the scales: the people of prayer, fasting, charity, and Hajj. Then the people of affliction will be brought, and no scales will be set up for them, nor any record spread open for them. Reward will be poured upon them in torrents, just as affliction was poured upon them in torrents. So the people of ease in the world [dunya] will wish that their bodies had been cut with scissors, due to what they see of the reward that the people of affliction take away." That is the meaning of His saying, the Almighty: "Indeed, the patient [sabiroon] will be given their reward without account."

a.g: Say, [O Muhammad], "Indeed, I have been commanded to worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion.
And I have been commanded to be the first [among you] of the Muslims."
Say, "Indeed I fear, if I should disobey my Lord, the punishment of a tremendous Day."
Say, "Allah [alone] do I worship, sincere to Him in my religion,
So worship what you will besides Him." Say, "Indeed, the losers are the ones who will lose themselves and their families on the Day of Resurrection. Unquestionably, that is the manifest loss."
They will have canopies of fire above them and below them, canopies. By that Allah threatens His servants. O My servants, then fear Me.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book3
Indeed, for them are canopies of the Fire [al-nar] from above them and canopies from beneath them. With that, Allah [Allah] makes His servants fear.

a.g: But those who have avoided Taghut, lest they worship it, and turned back to Allah - for them are good tidings. So give good tidings to My servants
Who listen to speech and follow the best of it. Those are the ones Allah has guided, and those are people of understanding.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k06
Indeed, for this reason, Allah described those who turn away from Satan [ash-shaytan] in it, with His saying: "Those who listen to speech [al-qawl] and follow the best of it."

a.g: Then, is one who has deserved the decree of punishment [to be guided]? Then, can you save one who is in the Fire?
But those who have feared their Lord - for them are chambers, above them chambers built high, beneath which rivers flow. [This is] the promise of Allah. Allah does not fail in [His] promise.

Do you not see that Allah sends down rain from the sky and makes it flow as springs [and rivers] in the earth; then He produces thereby crops of varying colors; then they dry and you see them turned yellow; then He makes them [scattered] debris. Indeed in that is a reminder for those of understanding.

So is one whose breast Allah has expanded to [accept] Islam and he is upon a light from his Lord [like one whose heart rejects it]? Then woe to those whose hearts are hardened against the remembrance of Allah. Those are in manifest error.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j3 k01
Indeed, likewise in the heart [qalb] there is an innate faculty called the Divine Light [al-nur al-ilahi], due to His saying, exalted is He: "Is he whose breast [sadr] God has expanded for Islam, so he is upon a light [nur] from his Lord?" And it has been called the intellect [al-'aql], and it has been called the inner insight [al-basira al-batina], and it has been called the light of faith [nur al-iman] and certainty [al-yaqin]. There is no meaning in busying oneself with the names, for the terminologies differ. The weak one imagines that the difference occurs in the meanings, because the weak one seeks the meanings from the words, and this is the opposite of what is required. The heart [qalb] is distinguished from all other parts of the body by a quality through which it perceives meanings that are neither imagined nor sensed, such as perceiving the creation of the world [khalq al-'alam] or its need for an Ancient Creator, a Manager, Wise, described with divine attributes. And it is permissible to name that innate faculty 'intellect' [al-'aql] on the condition that one does not understand from the term 'intellect' that by which the methods of disputation and debate are perceived, for the name 'intellect' has become famous with this [meaning], and for this reason some of the Sufis have censured it. Otherwise, the quality by which man is distinguished from the beasts and by which he perceives the knowledge [ma'rifa] of God, exalted is He, is the most noble of qualities, so it should not be censured. This innate faculty was created so that through it the realities [haqa'iq] of all matters may be known. The requirement of its nature is knowledge [ma'rifa] and understanding ['ilm], and that is its delight, just as the requirement of all other innate faculties is their delight.

a.g: Allah has sent down the best statement: a consistent Book wherein is reiteration. The skins shiver therefrom of those who fear their Lord; then their skins and their hearts relax at the remembrance of Allah. That is the guidance of Allah by which He guides whom He wills. And one whom Allah leaves astray - for him there is no guide.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k08
Indeed, His saying, the Most High: "Repeated verses [mathani] at which the skins of those who fear their Lord shiver, then their skins and their hearts soften to the remembrance of Allah." And all that occurs in the soul [nafs] following listening is a state of spiritual experience [wajd]. So tranquility [tuma'ninah], shivering [iqsh'iar], awe [khashyah], and the softening of the heart [qalb]—all of that is a state of spiritual experience [wajd]. And Allah, the Most High, has said: "The believers are only those whose hearts [qulub] tremble when Allah is mentioned." And He, the Most High, has said: "If We had sent down this Qur'an upon a mountain, you would have seen it humbled and split asunder from the fear of Allah." So trembling [wajal] and humility [khushu'] are a state of spiritual experience [wajd] from the category of spiritual states [ahwal], even if it is not from the category of unveilings [mukashafat]. But it may become a cause for unveilings [mukashafat] and spiritual promptings [tanbihat].

a.g: Then is he who will shield with his face the worst of the punishment on the Day of Resurrection [like one secure from it]? And it will be said to the wrongdoers, "Taste what you used to earn."
Those before them denied, and punishment came upon them from where they did not perceive.
So Allah made them taste disgrace in worldly life. But the punishment of the Hereafter is greater, if they only knew.
And We have certainly presented for the people in this Qur'an from every [kind of] example - that they might remember.
[It is] an Arabic Qur'an, without any deviance that they might become righteous.
Allah presents an example: a slave owned by quarreling partners and another belonging exclusively to one man - are they equal in comparison? Praise be to Allah! But most of them do not know.
Indeed, you are to die, and indeed, they are to die.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book10
Indeed, O Zubayr, you will die [tamūt], and indeed, they will die [yamūtūn]. Then, on the Day of Resurrection [yawm al-qiyāmah], before your Lord [rabbikum], you will dispute [takhtaṣimūn]. Zubayr said: "O Messenger of God, will what was between us in the world [al-dunyā] be repeated for us, along with the particulars of sins [khuṣūṣ al-dhunūb]?" He said: "Yes, it will indeed be repeated for you until you render to every possessor of a right [dhī ḥaqq] his right [ḥaqqah]." Zubayr said: "By God, the matter is severe. So who is more unjust than one who lies about Allah and denies the truth when it has come to him? Is there not in Hell a residence for the disbelievers?

Indeed, is not Allah sufficient for His servant [ʿabd]? So, the one who seeks sufficiency [kifāya] from other than Him and abandons reliance [tawakkul] is the one who denies this verse. For it is a question posed in the manner of compelling acknowledgment of the truth, like His saying: Has there not come upon man a period of time when he was not a thing remembered?

a.g: And whoever Allah guides - for him there is no misleader. Is not Allah Exalted in Might and Owner of Retribution?

And if you asked them, "Who created the heavens and the earth?" they would surely say, "Allah." Say, "Then have you considered what you invoke besides Allah? If Allah intended me harm, are they removers of His harm; or if He intended me mercy, are they withholders of His mercy?" Say, "Sufficient for me is Allah; upon Him [alone] rely the [wise] reliers."
Say, "O my people, work according to your position, [for] indeed, I am working; and you are going to know
To whom will come a torment disgracing him and on whom will descend an enduring punishment."

Indeed, We sent down to you the Book for the people in truth. So whoever is guided - it is for [the benefit of] his soul; and whoever goes astray only goes astray to its detriment. And you are not a manager over them.

Allah takes the souls at the time of their death, and those that do not die [He takes] during their sleep. Then He keeps those for which He has decreed death and releases the others for a specified term. Indeed in that are signs for a people who give thought.

Indeed, if you say: How can one reconcile Divine Oneness [tawhid] and Sacred Law [shar']? For the meaning of Oneness [tawhid] is that there is no agent [fa'il] except God, Exalted is He; and the meaning of the Sacred Law [shar'] is affirming actions [af'al] for the servants [ibad]. If the servant [abd] is an agent [fa'il], then how can God, Exalted is He, be the agent [fa'il]? And if God, Exalted is He, is the agent [fa'il], then how can the servant [abd] be an agent [fa'il]? An effect [maf'ul] between two agents [fa'ilayn] is not comprehensible? Then I say: Yes, that is not comprehensible if the agent [fa'il] has a single meaning. But if it has two meanings, and the name is a general term [mujmal] oscillating between them, there is no contradiction. Just as it is said: 'The commander [amir] killed so-and-so,' and it is said: 'The executioner [jallad] killed him.' However, the commander [amir] is a killer [qatil] in one sense, and the executioner [jallad] is a killer [qatil] in another sense. Likewise, the servant [abd] is an agent [fa'il] in one sense, and God, Mighty and Majestic, is an agent [fa'il] in another sense. For the meaning of God, Exalted is He, being the agent [fa'il] is that He is the Inventor [mukhtari'], the Bringer-into-Being [mawjid]. And the meaning of the servant [abd] being an agent [fa'il] is that he is the locus [mahall] in which power [qudra] was created after will [irada] was created in him, after knowledge [ilm] was created in him. Thus, power [qudra] became connected to will [irada], and movement [haraka] became connected to power [qudra] with the connection of a condition [shart] to what is conditioned [mashrut]. And it became connected to the power [qudra] of God with the connection of an effect [ma'lul] to its cause [illa] and the connection of the invented [mukhtara'] to the Inventor [mukhtari']. Everything that has a connection to a power [qudra], then the locus [mahall] of that power [qudra] is called an agent [fa'il] for it, however the connection may be. Just as the executioner [jallad] is called a killer [qatil] and the commander [amir] is called a killer [qatil], because the killing [qatl] was connected to the power [qudra] of both of them, but in two different ways. Therefore, it was called an action [fi'l] for both of them. Likewise is the connection of the foreordained things [maqdurat] to the two powers [qudratayn]. And due to the correspondence and alignment of this, God, Exalted is He, ascribed the actions [af'al] in the Qur'an at one time to the angels [mala'ika] and at another time to the servants [ibad], and He ascribed the very same actions [af'al] at another time to Himself. Thus, God, Exalted is He, said concerning death [mawt]: "Say, 'The Angel of Death [malak al-mawt] takes you'" (32:11). Then He, Mighty and Majestic, said: "It is God who takes the souls [anfus] at the time of their death [mawt]" (39:42).

a.g: Or have they taken other than Allah as intercessors? Say, "Even though they do not possess [power over] anything, nor do they reason?"
Say, "To Allah belongs [the right to allow] intercession entirely. To Him belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth. Then to Him you will be returned."
And when Allah is mentioned alone, the hearts of those who do not believe in the Hereafter shrink with aversion, but when those [worshipped] other than Him are mentioned, immediately they rejoice.
Say, "O Allah, Creator of the heavens and the earth, Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, You will judge between your servants concerning that over which they used to differ."

And if those who did wrong had all that is in the earth entirely and the like of it with it, they would [attempt to] ransom themselves thereby from the worst of the punishment on the Day of Resurrection. And there will appear to them from Allah that which they had not taken into account.

Indeed, while I was journeying on a path of mine, I inclined towards a tree to rest beneath it, and behold, I was with a shaykh who had drawn near. He said: 'Whoever is certain [yaqin] with what is after death [al-mawt] has girded the waistcloth of caution, and he has no abode in the world [al-dunya].' For indeed, the time for shame from You has come to me, and the time for turning back from turning away from You has come to me.' Then he said: 'Were it not for Your forbearance [hilm], my term would not contain me, and were it not for Your pardon ['afw], my hope in what is with You would not expand.' Then he departed and left me. If you ask: "Where, then, is the proper place for hope [ar-rajā'] and its praiseworthy position?" Then know that it is praiseworthy in two situations: The first is concerning the disobedient sinner who is immersed [in sin], when the thought of repentance occurs to him. Allah, the Exalted, says: "Say, 'O My servants who have transgressed against themselves [by sinning], do not despair [lā taqnaṭū] of the mercy of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful. And return [in repentance] to your Lord.'" He commanded them to return [al-inābah]. And He, the Exalted, says: "And indeed, I am Forgiving to whoever repents and believes and does righteousness and then continues in guidance." So, if one anticipates forgiveness alongside repentance, then he is a true hopeful one [rājin]. But if one anticipates forgiveness while persisting [in sin], then he is deluded.

And He, the Exalted, said: "And you assumed an evil assumption [ẓann as-sū'], and you became a ruined people." So he went out to them and gave them hope [rajjāhum] and stirred their longing.

Or [lest] it say when it sees the punishment, "If only I had another turn so I could be among the doers of good."
But yes, there had come to you My verses, but you denied them and were arrogant, and you were among the disbelievers.
And on the Day of Resurrection you will see those who lied about Allah [with] their faces blackened. Is there not in Hell a residence for the arrogant?

And contemplate first what strikes the hearing of the inhabitants of the graves from the intensity of the blowing of the Trumpet [as-sur]. For it is a single cry, through which the graves split open over the heads of the dead, and they surge forth all at once. So imagine yourself, having leapt up, your face altered, your body dust-covered from your head to your feet with the dust of your grave, stunned from the intensity of the blow, your eyes fixed towards the call. And the creation has surged forth in a single surge from the graves in which their tribulation was prolonged, and alarm and terror have roused them, added to what was with them of sorrows, griefs, and the intensity of waiting for the final outcome of the matter, as the Most High has said: "And the Trumpet [as-sur] will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on." So if there were nothing before the dead except the terror of that blowing, that would be sufficient to be guarded against. For it is a blowing and a cry through which whoever is in the heavens and the earth falls dead—meaning they die from it—except whom Allah wills, and that is some of the angels. And for that reason, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "How can I be at ease when the bearer of the Trumpet [as-sur] has placed the horn in his mouth, lowered his forehead, and inclined his ear, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow?" Muqatil said: The Trumpet [as-sur] is the horn. That is because Israfil, upon him be peace, places his mouth upon the horn like the form of a trumpet, and the circumference of the head of the horn is like the width of the heavens and the earth. And he is fixing his gaze towards the Throne, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow the first blowing. And when he blows, whoever is in the heavens and the earth falls dead—meaning every living creature dies from the intensity of the terror—except whom Allah wills, and that is Jibril, Mika'il, Israfil, and the Angel of Death. Then He commands the Angel of Death to seize the soul of Jibril, then the soul of Mika'il, then the soul of Israfil. Then He commands the Angel of Death, and he dies. Then the creation remains after the first blowing in the Barzakh for forty years. Then Allah, the Most High, revives Israfil and commands him to blow the second blowing. That is His saying, the Most High: "Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on"—upon their feet, looking towards the Resurrection. And the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "When I was sent, I was sent to the bearer of the Trumpet [as-sur], and he gestured with it to his mouth, and placed one foot forward and the other back, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow. So beware of the blowing." So contemplate the creatures and their abasement, their brokenness, and their submission at the time of being sent forth, in fear of this blow and in waiting for what will be decreed for them of felicity or wretchedness. And you are among them, broken as they are broken, bewildered as they are bewildered. Rather, if you were in the world [ad-dunya] among the affluent and the wealthy who live in luxury, then the kings of the earth...

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book10
Indeed, before the commencement of the questioning, the light of the Throne [al-'arsh] will appear, **"And the earth will shine with the light of its Lord"** [Qur'an 39:69]. And every servant ['abd] will be certain [yaqin] with the certainty [yaqin] that the Compeller [al-Jabbar] is turning to question the servants. And each one will think that no one sees him but Him, and that he alone is the one taken for the taking and the questioning, to the exclusion of all others.

a.g: And every soul will be fully compensated [for] what it did; and He is most knowing of what they do.

And those who disbelieved will be driven to Hell in groups until, when they reach it, its gates are opened and its keepers will say, "Did there not come to you messengers from yourselves, reciting to you the verses of your Lord and warning you of the meeting of this Day of yours?" They will say, "Yes, but the word of punishment has come into effect upon the disbelievers.
[To them] it will be said, "Enter the gates of Hell to abide eternally therein, and wretched is the residence of the arrogant."

But those who feared their Lord will be driven to Paradise in groups until, when they reach it while its gates have been opened and its keepers say, "Peace be upon you; you have become pure; so enter it to abide eternally therein," [they will enter].
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book10
Indeed, and from 'Asim bin Damrah, from 'Ali, may God honor his face, that he mentioned the Fire and magnified its affair with a mention I do not retain, then he said: **"And those who feared their Lord will be led to Paradise in groups."** [Quran 39:73] Until, when they reached a gate from among its gates, they found at it a tree, from beneath its trunk emerge two springs flowing. So they proceeded to one of them as they were commanded to do, and drank from it, and it removed what was in their bellies of harm or distress. Then they proceeded to the other and purified themselves from it, and there flowed upon them the freshness of bliss, so their hair never changed after that forever, nor did their heads become disheveled, as if they had been anointed with oil. Then they reached Paradise, and its keepers said to them: "Peace be upon you, you have done well, so enter it, abiding eternally."

a.g: And they will say, "Praise to Allah, who has fulfilled for us His promise and made us inherit the earth [so] we may settle in Paradise wherever we will. And excellent is the reward of [righteous] workers."

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book2
Know that God the Exalted has coupled gratitude [shukr] with remembrance [dhikr] in His Book, even though He has said: "And the remembrance of God is greater" {}. Thus He the Exalted said: "So remember Me, I will remember you, and be grateful to Me, and do not be ungrateful" {}. And He the Exalted said: "What would God do with your punishment if you are grateful and believe" {}. And He the Exalted said: "And We will reward the grateful" {}. And God has made gratitude [shukr] the key to the speech of the people of Paradise, for He the Exalted said: "And they will say: 'Praise be to God, who has been true to His promise to us'" {}. And He said: "And the last of their call will be: 'Praise be to God, Lord of the worlds'" {}.

a.g: And you will see the angels surrounding the Throne, exalting [Allah] with praise of their Lord. And it will be judged between them in truth, and it will be said, "[All] praise to Allah, Lord of the worlds."
